column4: I ran the update manager earlier today. Before I did it, ubuntu booted up by itself and no GRUB menu was present. Now, however, I have a choice between two ubuntu's (they have the same ver. # after them) and two recovery options. Is there a way I can get it to boot up without displaying the GRUB menu?
there is a program called "startup manager" you can install from the repos.. it has settings for showing grub or not, amongst others
thanks. I'll check it out.
I downloaded the startup manager, but  I can't find where to turn off the grub screen.
hmm.. try the "Show bootloader menu" option
I don't believe I have that option.
on the first tab? at the bottom there is three checkboxes?
the tab is called "Boot options"
oh.. perhaps you need something else to be installed before it shows that option.. weird..
Yup. I see it. In the Misc Section, I have show boot splash and show text during boot
hmm.. before those two I have "Show bootloader menu" checkbox.. strange
well.. we can do it manually then..
I have no idea how to do anything manually in ubuntu. xD
run this in a terminal "gksudo gedit /boot/grub/menu.lst"
the file you're seeing now is the main configuration file for grub.. with all the kernels available, settings for them and so on
All I see is hiddenmenu
that's the one.. remove the # before it.. so it says        hiddenmenu     instead of      #hiddenmenu
there's no # in front of it
huh.. and you still get the grub menu? the one with the kernel and a recovery mode and perhaps a memtest option?
Well, I have a like 2.6.6 and a 2.6.8 or something like that. I ran the update manager earlier today. It started doing this after I updated
ok.. lets try this.. open a terminal.. run "sudo update-grub" ... it will take a couple of seconds or more.. let it run.. then try rebooting and see if the menu is still there
